description: Overview for cluster VictoriaMetrics v1.79.0 or higher

panels.description: How many datapoints are in storage
panels.title: Total datapoints

panels.description: The minimum free disk space left among all storage nodes.
panels.title: Min free disk space

panels.description: Average disk usage per datapoint.
panels.title: Bytes per point

panels.description: Total size of allowed memory via flag `-memory.allowedPercent` for all VM components
panels.title: Allowed memory

panels.description: How many entries inverted index contains. This value is proportional to the number of unique timeseries in storage(cardinality).
panels.title: Index size

panels.description: Total amount of used disk space
panels.title: Disk space usage

panels.description: Total number of available CPUs for all VM components.
panels.title: Available CPU

panels.description: Total size of available memory for all VM components.
panels.title: Available memory

panels.description: How many datapoints are inserted into storage per second by protocol and accountID
panels.title: Datapoints ingestion rate ($instance)

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Requests rate ($instance)

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Requests error rate ($instance)

panels.description:
The less time it takes is better.
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Query duration ($instance)

panels.description: RPC errors are interconnection errors between cluster components. Errors rate should be 0 if network connection is stable and all components are up and operational.
panels.title: RPC errors ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of logging the messages by their level. Unexpected spike in rate is a good reason to check logs.
panels.title: Logging rate

panels.description: Shows the percentage of remaining disk space at `-storageDataPath` by instance

targets.expr:
sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance"}) by(instance) /
(
  sum(vm_free_disk_space_bytes{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance"}) by(instance) +
  sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance"}) by(instance)
)

panels.title: Disk space used ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the number of active time series with new data points inserted during the last hour. High value may result in ingestion slowdown. 

See following link for details:
panels.title: Active time series ($instance)

panels.description:
Amount of used memory (resident)
Contains memory share which can be freed by OS when needed.
panels.title: RSS memory usage ($instance)

panels.description: RSS share for memory allocated by the process itself. This share cannot be freed by the OS, so it must be taken into account by OOM killer.
panels.title: RSS anonymous memory usage ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the CPU usage in the percentage from the limit.
panels.title: CPU percentage ($instance)

panels.description:
Panel shows the number of open file descriptors in the OS.
Reaching the limit of open files can cause various issues and must be prevented.

See how to change limits here https://medium.com/@muhammadtriwibowo/set-permanently-ulimit-n-open-files-in-ubuntu-4d61064429a
panels.title: Open FDs ($instance)

panels.description: Shows average GC duration by instance
panels.title: GC duration ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the number of bytes read/write from the storage layer.
panels.title: Disk writes/reads ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the rate and total number of new series created over last 24h.

High churn rate tightly connected with database performance and may result in unexpected OOM's or slow queries. It is recommended to always keep an eye on this metric to avoid unexpected cardinality "explosions".

The higher churn rate is, the more resources required to handle it. Consider to keep the churn rate as low as possible.

To investigate stats about most expensive series use `api/v1/status/tsdb` handler. More details here https://docs.victoriametrics.com/Cluster-VictoriaMetrics.html#url-format

Good references to read:
* https://www.robustperception.io/cardinality-is-key
* https://valyala.medium.com/high-cardinality-tsdb-benchmarks-victoriametrics-vs-timescaledb-vs-influxdb-13e6ee64dd6b
panels.title: Churn rate ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of adding new items to the index. It should correlate with `Slow inserts` and `Churn rate` graphs and could help to determine the pressure on indexdb.
panels.title: IndexDB items rate ($instance)

panels.description:
The percentage of slow inserts comparing to total insertion rate during the last 5 minutes. 

The less value is better. If percentage remains high (>10%) during extended periods of time, then it is likely more RAM is needed for optimal handling of the current number of active time series. 

In general, VictoriaMetrics requires ~1KB or RAM per active time series, so it should be easy calculating the required amounts of RAM for the current workload according to capacity planning docs. But the resulting number may be far from the real number because the required amounts of memory depends on may other factors such as the number of labels per time series and the length of label values.
panels.title: Slow inserts

panels.description: Slow queries according to `search.logSlowQueryDuration` flag, which is `5s` by default.
panels.title: Slow queries rate ($instance)

panels.description: The value is above 0 when the vmstorage at the given `addr` communicates to the given vminsert node that it cannot accept new data because it is in the read-only mode.
panels.title: Storage in readonly status for vminsert ($instance)

panels.description:
VictoriaMetrics limits the number of labels per each metric with `-maxLabelsPerTimeseries` command-line flag.

This prevents from ingesting metrics with too many labels. The value of `maxLabelsPerTimeseries` must be adjusted for your workload.

When limit is exceeded (graph is > 0) - extra labels are dropped, which could result in unexpected identical time series.
panels.title: Labels limit exceeded ($instance)

panels.description: Merge assist happens when vmstorage can't keep up with merging parts. This is usually a sign of overload for vmstorage.
panels.title: Assisted merges ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the percentage of used cache size from the allowed size by type. 
Values close to 100% show the maximum potential utilization.
Values close to 0% show that cache is underutilized.
panels.title: Cache usage % by vmstorage ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows number of pushed and sent rows. 
* `Pushed rows` - rows added to internal inserter buffers before send
* `Sent rows` - successfully transmitted rows to storage nodes

Please note, it could be that `Sent > Pushed` because of the replication factor.
panels.title: Rows ($instance)

panels.description:
Rate of RPC errors by type:
* `Connection` - the number of connection errors to vmstorage node
* `Dial` -  the number of dial errors to vmstorage node.
* `Handshake` - the number of handshake errors to vmstorage node
* `Rerouted` - errors appeared during rerouting of rows from un-healthy storage node to a healthy one.
panels.title: RPC errors ($instance)

panels.description: The number of rows rerouted to the vmstorage node from other nodes when they were unhealthy.
panels.title: Rows ($instance) rerouted to

panels.description: The number of rows rerouted from the vmstorage node to healthy nodes when the given node was unhealthy.
panels.title: Rows ($instance) rerouted from

panels.description: The number of rows or bytes that vminesrt internal buffer contains at the moment.
panels.title: Pending

panels.description: Network usage by internal VictoriaMetrics RPC protocol
panels.title: RPC network usage ($instance)

panels.description: VictoriaMetrics stores various caches in RAM. Memory size for these caches may be limited with -`memory.allowedPercent` flag. Line `max allowed` shows max allowed memory size for cache.
panels.title: Cache size ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the percentage of used cache size from the allowed size by type. 
Values close to 100% show the maximum potential utilization.
Values close to 0% show that cache is underutilized.

targets.expr:
sum(vm_cache_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(type) / 
sum(vm_cache_size_max_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(type)

panels.title: Cache usage % ($instance)

panels.description: VictoriaMetrics stores various caches in RAM. Memory size for these caches may be limited with -`memory.allowedPercent` flag. Line `max allowed` shows max allowed memory size for cache.
panels.title: Cache hit ratio ($instance)

panels.description: Shows how many rows per second every storage node accepts. This metric doesn't show all stored rows since some of them may be dropped because of wrong timestamps or decode errors.
panels.title: Ingestion rate ($instance)

targets.expr: vm_free_disk_space_bytes{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance"} / ignoring(path) ((rate(vm_rows_added_to_storage_total{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance"}[1d]) - ignoring(type) rate(vm_deduplicated_samples_total{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance", type="merge"}[1d])) * scalar(sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance", type!="indexdb"}) / sum(vm_rows{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance", type!="indexdb"})))

panels.title: Storage full ETA ($instance)

panels.description: Shows how many datapoints are in the storage.
panels.title: Datapoints ($instance)

panels.description: How many datapoints are in RAM queue waiting to be written into storage. The number of pending data points should be in the range from 0 to `2*<ingestion_rate>`, since VictoriaMetrics pushes pending data to persistent storage every second. The index datapoints value in general is much lower.
panels.title: Pending datapoints ($instance)

panels.description: Shows amount of on-disk space occupied by data points.
panels.title: Disk space usage (datapoints) ($instance)

panels.description: Shows amount of on-disk space occupied by inverted index.
panels.title: Disk space usage (index)  ($instance)

panels.description: The number of on-going merges in storage nodes.  It is expected to have high numbers for `storage/small` metric.
panels.title: Active merges ($instance)

panels.description: The number of rows merged per second by storage nodes.
panels.title: Merge speed

panels.description: Shows how many rows were ignored on insertion due to corrupted or out of retention timestamps.
panels.title: Rows ignored ($instance)

panels.description:
The max number of data parts of LSM tree across all storage nodes.
High number of parts (the hard limit is 512) is an evidence of slow merge performance - check the resource utilization.
* `indexdb` - inverted index
* `storage/small` - recently added parts of data ingested into storage (hot data)
* `storage/big` -  small parts gradually merged into big parts (cold data)
panels.title: LSM parts ($instance)

panels.description: Value > 0 means vmstorage is in readonly mode.
panels.title: Readonly mode

panels.description:
Shows how many ongoing insertions (not API /write calls) on disk are taking place, where:
* `max` - equal to number of CPUs;
* `current` - current number of goroutines busy with inserting rows into underlying storage.

Every successful API /write call results into flush on disk. The `max` is an internal limit and can't be changed. It is always equal to the number of CPUs. 

When `current` hits `max` constantly, it means storage is overloaded and requires more CPU or faster disk.
panels.title: Concurrent flushes on disk ($instance)

panels.description: Request rate accepted by vmselect nodes
panels.title: Requests rate ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the max number of concurrent selects across instances.
* `max` - equal to number of CPU * 2 by default. May be configured with `search.maxConcurrentRequests` flag
* `current` - current number of goroutines busy with processing requests

When `current` hits `max` constantly, it means one or more vmselect nodes are overloaded and require more CPU or better load balancing. If CPU panel shows there are free resources - try increasing  `search.maxConcurrentRequests`.
panels.title: Concurrent selects ($instance)

panels.description: 99th percentile of number of series read per query.
panels.title: Series read per query ($instance)

panels.description: 99th percentile of number of raw samples read per query.
panels.title: Rows read per query ($instance)

panels.description: 99th percentile of number of raw samples read per queried series.
panels.title: Rows read per series ($instance)

panels.description:
99th percentile of number of raw samples scanner per query.

This number can exceed number of RowsReadPerQuery if `step` query arg passed to [/api/v1/query_range](https://prometheus.io/docs/prometheus/latest/querying/api/#range-queries) is smaller than the lookbehind window set in square brackets of [rollup function](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/MetricsQL.html#rollup-functions). For example, if `increase(some_metric[1h])` is executed with the `step=5m`, then the same raw samples on a hour time range are scanned `1h/5m=12` times. See [this article](https://valyala.medium.com/how-to-optimize-promql-and-metricsql-queries-85a1b75bf986) for details.
panels.title: Rows scanned per series ($instance)

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Requests rate ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows how many ongoing insertions are taking place.
* `max` - equal to number of CPU * 4 by default. May be configured with `maxConcurrentInserts` flag;
* `current` - current number of goroutines busy with processing requests.

`-maxConcurrentInserts` limits the number of insert requests which may be actively processed at any given point in time. All the other insert requests are queued for up to `-insert.maxQueueDuration` in the hope they will get a chance to be processed. This queue is used mostly for absorbing spikes for incoming insert request rate.

When `current` hits `max` constantly, it means vminsert node is overloaded and requires more CPU or higher limits.
panels.title: Concurrent inserts ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the saturation level of connection between vminsert and vmstorage components. If the threshold of 0.9sec is reached, then the connection is saturated by more than 90% and vminsert won't be able to keep up. This usually means that more vminsert or vmstorage nodes must be added to the cluster in order to increase the total number of vminsert -> vmstorage links.
panels.title: Storage connection saturation ($instance)

panels.description: Shows if vmstorage node is reachable for vminsert. If below 1 means vmstorage is not reachable at this moment of time.
panels.title: Storage reachability ($instance)

title: VictoriaMetrics - cluster
